choices.text: Cuff pressure should be kept less than 25 mm hg.
low-pressure high-volume cuffs provide better protection against aspiration.
Nitrous oxide can cause the cuff pressure to increase.
Bevelling of the tip of the ETT provides better visualization of vocal cords during intubation.

questions.text: With tracheal tubes, all are true except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

CUFF OF ETT:

There are 2 types of cuffs that endotracheal tubes come with.

•	High pressure low volume cuff: these provide better protection against aspiration at the cost of increased risk of tracheal mucosal ischemia and subsequent tracheal necrosis.

•	Low-pressure high-volume cuff: these do not cause tracheal mucosal necrosis as they distributed the pressure on the tracheal wall but there is slightly higher risk of aspiration as compared to high pressure cuffs.
•	The ideal intracuff pressure in a healthy adult should be kept less than 25 mmhg. This is the pressure of tracheal mucosal capillaries. 
•	Bevel of the tip always faces left in an endotracheal tube and it improves visualization of vocal cords during intubation.

choices.text: It's the end of the case and even if one lung isn’t ventilated it won’t have any clinical significance.
Placement of the endotracheal tube at the level of the carina is optimal.
Both lungs appear to be inflated on the chest x-ray; this is likely because the lungs are being ventilated via the Murphy eye of the endotracheal tube.

Both lungs appear to be inflated on the chest x-ray; this is likely because the positive pressure ventilation is blowing the carina away from the endotracheal tube and allowing both lungs to be ventilated.

questions.text: A 46-year-old female undergoes an uneventful exploratory laparotomy. Chest and abdominal x-rays are performed to evaluate for a lost sponge in the counts at the end of the case. The chest x-ray incidentally reveals that the endotracheal tube is sitting just at the carina. One of the trainee surgeons becomes worried and asks for the tube to be adjusted. However, the anesthetist does not show concern. Which of the following best explains why the anesthetist is unconcerned?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	The Murphy eye is a safety mechanism to allow for ventilation to continue even if the tip of the endotracheal tube is hubbed against the wall of the endobronchial tree.
•	Nearly all endotracheal tubes have a Murphy eye for this purpose.
•	The Murphy eye is a second smaller hole off the side of the distal end of the endotracheal tube (positioned 90 degrees from the tip).
•	Optimal placement of the tip of the endotracheal tube is at the level of the T2-T4 vertebrae in the middle third of the trachea, not at the carina. 
•	It is nice that both lungs appear to be inflated on the chest x-ray, but this is not because the positive pressure ventilation is blowing the carina away from the endotracheal tube. 
•	Answer 1 is also incorrect, the endotracheal tube will come out shortly as the case is over, but it is not a good explanation of why the anaesthesiologist is unconcerned. 
•	It is necessary to ventilate both lungs throughout the entire case properly.

choices.text: A larger sized LMA than usual

questions.text: A 54-year-old professional singer presents to the hospital with a ruptured appendix. He is scheduled for an emergency laparoscopic appendectomy. He is very worried about endotracheal intubation because of his profession. He requests the use of a laryngeal mask airway (LMA) and does not want to be intubated. What is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	LMAs are frequently used to provide a patent airway during general anesthesia. While most providers prefer to use them for patients who are breathing spontaneously, positive pressure ventilation can be provided with a well seated LMA.
•	LMA's do not protect against gastric content aspiration. Aspiration of gastric contents can be fatal.
•	The difference between a 1st and 2nd generation LMA is in the cuff material and a separate access hole to the esophagus. They are designed to provide a higher seal pressure allowing for higher positive pressure ventilation.
•	In an emergency procedure, an LMA is not a good choice for primary airway management as LMAs do not protect against gastric content aspiration. 
•	Endotracheal intubation is a gold standard method of airway access when there is increased risk of aspiration.

choices.text: Ask for a large plastic adhesive, cut a hole into it and place over the patient's mouth to make a seal.
Rush to tracheostomy as mask ventilation is failing.
Attempt to find a larger mask to make a better seal.
Place a second-generation laryngeal mask airway (LMA)

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a history of obesity is undergoing an elective herniorrhaphy. Anesthesia is successfully induced. Right after giving a muscle relaxant, positive pressure ventilation by face mask fails to provide an adequate seal. His oxygen saturation of the patient begins to fall. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	After induction of anesthesia, including a muscle relaxant, maintaining pre-oxygenation and some ventilation is of paramount importance to avoid hypoxia. 
•	Especially in larger individuals, redundant tissue may make positive pressure ventilation difficult. 
•	Once the face mask fails to provide an adequate seal, an LMA is a good choice to provide a seal further down the airway.
•	The LMA is designed to create a seal around the larynx to allow positive pressure ventilation up to a certain pressure, which can vary between patients and the design of the LMA. 
•	Once the patient's saturation begins to fall, swift and decisive action such as inserting an LMA will help to prevent further hypoxia.
•	In addition to bypassing facial features, missing teeth, and full beards, LMAs can also be useful to slide past redundant pharyngeal tissues which might obstruct the upper airway.
•	LMA's have different designs and features, such as silicone cuffs, gastric access ports, non-inflatable gel cuffs. 
•	2nd generation LMAs often provide higher seal pressure to allow for higher positive pressure ventilation pressures and are preferred in a rescue situation. 
•	LMA's, preferably 2nd generation, should be immediately available during induction of anesthesia if airway rescue becomes necessary.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient is scheduled for an appendectomy. The patient is administered glycopyrrolate along with other routine drugs just before intubating the patient. Which of the following side effects is expected postoperatively?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	Glycopyrrolate is a muscarinic anticholinergic agent. 
•	It is used to reduce salivary secretions before surgery. 
•	Glycopyrrolate causes urinary retention due to its parasympatholytic action.
•	A blockade of reflexive vagal cardiac inhibition reflexes during both intubation and anesthetic induction occurs during glycopyrrolate use. 
•	The intravenous formulation of glycopyrrolate is classically used to reverse vagal reflexes and bradycardia intraoperatively.
•	Glycopyrrolate may be administered to reverse the neuromuscular blockade due to nondepolarizing muscle relaxants postoperatively and is frequently used in conjunction with neostigmine, a cholinesterase inhibitor. 
•	It is also used to reduce severe or chronic drooling in pediatric patients with neurologic conditions, such as cerebral palsy.
•	Glycopyrrolate does not cause chest pain or bradycardia.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man presents to the clinic for pre-operative evaluation for a laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia. The patient says he is feeling well, remembers many years ago, was diagnosed with some joint condition, and was advised to take mediations for which he would have to do blood tests regularly. He was not interested in doing the regular blood tests and seeing a clinician regularly, hence he never took treatment for the disease. On examination has bilateral ulnar deviation and subluxation of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints. Hand X-ray shows erosions of MCP and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints. Rheumatoid factor (RF) and anti-CCP antibodies are positive. 
The patient also complaints of stiffness in his neck. Which of the following is the next best step in the pre operative evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	Rheumatoid arthritis is a disease of the synovium. 
•	At the spine, C1 and C2 are the only vertebral bodies that have synovium. 
•	Hence, the only vertebral bodies which RA involves are C1 and C2. 
•	When RA affects the synovium tissue between these C1 (atlas) and C2 (axis), it may result in abnormal movement of the atlas relative to the axis. This abnormal movement may result in injury to the spinal cord.
•	The involvement of the atlantoaxial joint generally occurs in patients with long-standing RA. These patients often have severe peripheral disease, joint deformities of the hands as a result of RA. Erosion might be present on radiographs.
•	Most of the time, these patients have not been adequately managed for RA. This may be due to a lack of regular follow up for RA due to nonadherence or other reasons.
•	When RA patients are about to undergo general anesthesia, it is best to have an X-ray of cervical spine to evaluate for atlantoaxial instability to prevent any damage to the spinal cord at the time of intubation.

choices.text: Cannot comment on the level of risk

questions.text: A 67-year-old male with a past medical history of hypertension, insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, and end-stage renal disease presents for open reduction and internal fixation of the right humerus fracture following a fall. His vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 145/78 mmHg, a heart rate of 85/min, respiratory rate of 16/min, and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. Laboratory values are noted for hemoglobin of 10.4 g/dL, sodium of 147 mEq/L, potassium of 5.6 mEq/L, urea of 43 mg/dL, and a creatinine of 2.4 mg/dL. Serum glucose is 242 mg/dL. Using the revised cardiac risk index, what is this patient's risk of perioperative major adverse cardiovascular events?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

choices.text: Keep the patient paralyzed after intubation so he cannot self-extubate himself.
Plan tracheostomy as the patient has a difficult airway.
Place "Difficult Airway" sign outside of the patient's room
Avoid suctioning the patient as it will traumatize the tissue and it will lead to airway oedema.

questions.text: A 72-year-old male with COPD, congestive heart failure, diabetes mellitus, and hypothyroidism presents to the emergency department with cough and shortness of breath. The patient is found to have acute on chronic hypercapnic respiratory failure. His pH on arterial blood gas is 7.1, pCO2 90 mmHg, and pO2 100 mmHg on a nonrebreather mask. Upon evaluating his mouth, the clinician is unable to pass more than two fingers between upper and lower teeth. Because of the possibility of a difficult airway, the patient is intubated with a video laryngoscope after giving intravenous etomidate and rocuronium. The patient is now transferred to ICU. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


•	The 3-3-2 rule helps to predict difficult airway. This patient has fewer than 2 fingers width between upper and lower teeth which predicts difficult airway.
•	In the case of a difficult airway, the patient is usually intubated with rapid sequence intubation where paralytic medications are given. 
•	These medications should not be given continuously once the patient is intubated. The continuous infusion of paralytic medication increases the risk of myopathy.
•	Once the patient with difficult airway is intubated, it is important that the interprofessional team in the ICU is aware of the patient's difficult airway. This can be achieved by placing the "Difficult Airway" sign outside of the patient's room.
•	"Difficult Airway" sign allows respiratory therapists to have emergency intubation kit ready in the ICU if patient's self-extubates or fails planned extubation.

choices.text: Regular endotracheal tube and a bronchial blocker

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is admitted for elective left-sided lobectomy of upper lobe for lung nodule with suspicion of malignancy. She was diagnosed with a 1.2 cm pulmonary nodule 3 months ago. On repeat CT chest, the size of the nodule increased to 3 cm. During anesthesia, what is the best device for intraoperative ventilation of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

1: Absolute indications

  • Risk of soilage
  • Control of ventilation
  • Bronchopulmonary lavage      

2: Relative indications

  • Surgical exposure - high priority
  • Thoracoabdominal aneurysm repair
  • Pneumonectomy
  • Upper lobectomy         

3: Surgical exposure - low priority

  • Middle and lower lobe resection
  • Oesophageal resection
  • Thoracoscopy
  • Thoracic spine surgery

questions.text: Comment on the difficulty of intubation by looking at the following image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cormack and lehane classification:
It is a classification based on view of laryngeal structures based on direct laryngoscopy
It has 4 classes
Class i: entire glottis is visible
Class ii: predominantly posterior commissure is visible
Class iii: only epiglottis is visible
Class iv: no glottic structures can be seen
Class i and ii are considered as easy intubation and iii and iv are difficult.

choices.text: Entry into the right sided bronchus

questions.text: A 40-year-old chronic smoker was scheduled for cholecystectomy under general anesthesia. He was induced with propofol and vecuronium and started on isoflurane for maintenance of anesthesia. During the procedure, the following capnograph plot was observed. What is the possible cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	This bifid waveform represents the differential ventilation of two lungs. 
•	as the ETT is positioned mainly in the right main bronchus, the airflow through the right lung is the best, and right-sided gas forms the first (brisk and steep) part of the waveform. 
•	Afterwards, one notices that there is a secondary transitional phase, which is the gas from the left lung escaping slowly up into the ETT. 
•	Of course, if the left lung was completely isolated (i.e. you have the cuff inflated in such a way as to block it totally) you would not see this waveform.

questions.text: Which of the following would result in the greatest decrease in the arterial haemoglobin saturation (Spo2) value measured by the dual-wavelength pulse oximeter?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	Pulse oximeters estimate arterial hemoglobin saturation (Sao2) by measuring the amount of light transmitted through a pulsatile vascular tissue bed. 
•	Pulse oximeters can function accurately when only two hemoglobin species, oxyhemoglobin and reduced hemoglobin, are present. 
•	The administration of intravenous dyes can result in inaccurate SpO2 readings. Methylene blue leads to a transient, marked decrease in SpO2 down to 65%. Indigo carmine and indocyanine green also artificially decrease SpO2 measurements, although to a lesser extent than methylene blue.

choices.text: They are reliable even in the situation of shock.
They tend to give falsely low readings in patients with carbon monoxide toxicity.
They are useful as they provide an indication of the adequacy of a patient’s minute ventilation.
Higher number on the reading indicates a predominantly oxygenated blood.

questions.text: Regarding pulse oximeters:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	Pulse oximetry is reliable to about 70%. 
•	Carbon monoxide toxicity tends to give falsely high readings. 
•	Methemoglobinemia gives falsely low readings. 
•	They only give information on oxygenation. 
•	Quality of ventilation is best seen in capnography. 
•	A well preoxygenated patient may have 5 minutes of apnoea before a change in oxygen saturations is detected. 
•	The relative absorbance of light at different wavelengths is the principle behind the device. 
•	At the 660 nm (visible red) point, deoxyhaemoglobin absorbs more light. 
•	At the 940 nm (infrared) point, this is reversed.

choices.text: An adult patient under muscle relaxation.
A patient with a bispectral index monitor
An American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA)physical status V patient

questions.text: Which of the following patients is most likely to experience intraoperative awareness under anesthesia except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	Intraoperative awareness has an incidence estimated to be between 0.1% and 0.2%.
•	The incidence of awareness in the pediatric population is up to 10 times higher.
•	Besides age, other risk factors for intraoperative awareness include:
•	patient-related risk factors (history of substance abuse, more comorbid medical conditions/ higher ASA PS)
•	surgical risk factors (emergency surgery, trauma surgery)
•	anesthetic risk factors (use of muscle relaxants, absence of benzodiazepines).
•	BISPECTRAL INDEX ( BIS) is a monitor to assess the depth of anesthesia. It uses processed frontal eeg to determine the stage of anesthesia.
•	Advantages of the BIS monitor includes more adequate titration of anesthetic agents, faster anesthetic emergence, and probability of recall.

choices.text: The anesthesiologist immediately changed the endotracheal tube with a larger tube
The anesthesiologist immediately deepened the plane of anesthesia by a bolus dose of propofol
The anesthesiologist changed the ventilator settings to higher tidal volume
The anesthesiologist informed the surgeon to stop the surgery

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient is posted for laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia. The patient has a past medical history of asthma on regular treatment with last exacerbation a month back. Rest all investigations are normal. Standard induction is done with propofol and fentanyl with vecuronium as muscle relaxant and cuffed endotracheal tube is inserted and confirmed in position using a capnography trace on the monitor. Shortly after the commencement of the surgery, the ventilator suddenly starts showing alarm of increased peak airway pressures and the capnography waveform changes to image A. the anaesthesiologist immediately identifies the problem and intervenes and after 10 mins the capnograph changes to image B. which of the following is true about the intervention by the anaesthesiologist?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Intraoperative bronchospasm
•	Bronchospasm is is a reversible reflex spasm of the smooth muscle in the bronchi.
•	Bronchospasm is vagally mediated and caused by histamine, or one of many noxious stimuli, including cold air, inhaled irritants, and instrumentation (eg, tracheal intubation, surgical stimulation in light planes of anesthesia).
•	Bronchospasm is mediated by vagal afferents which result in an increase in cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP).
•	It is more common in asthmatics.

Bronchospasm: Manifestations
•	Rapidly increasing peak inspiratory pressure (plateau pressure unchanged)
•	Wheezing
•	Slowly increasing wave on the capnograph ( shark fin appearance)
•	Decreasing exhaled tidal volumes
Bronchospasm: Acute Treatment
1) Deepen anesthetic – increase volatile anesthetic concentration 
All volatile anesthetic agents are bronchodilators
Propofol or ketamine can be used to deepen the plane as well.
Ketamine has additional Broncho dilating effect
2) Consider alternative causes of high airway pressures eg. kinked tube, endobronchial intubation, etc.
3) Inhaled β2 -agonists – delivered to the inspiratory limb of the circuit through a metered dose inhaler or nebulized. If the severity of bronchospasm prohibits delivery of inhaled beta agonists, consider infusions of IV agonists such as terbutaline or epinephrine.
4) Consider administering intravenous steroids

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the ICU after elective repair of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. His vital signs are stable, but he requires a sodium nitroprusside infusion at a rate of 10 μg/kg/min to keep the systolic blood pressure below 110 mm Hg. The Sao2 is 98% with controlled ventilation at 12 breaths/min and an Fio2 of 0.60. After 3 days, his Sao2 decreases to 85% on the pulse oximeter. Chest x-ray film and results of physical examination are unchanged. Which of the following would most likely account for this desaturation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


•	The metabolism of nitroprusside in the body requires the conversion of oxyhaemoglobin (Fe++) to methaemoglobin (Fe+++). 
•	The presence of sufficient quantities of methaemoglobin in the blood will cause the pulse oximeter to read 85% saturation regardless of the true arterial saturation. 
•	Cyanide toxicity is also a possibility in any patient who is receiving nitroprusside. 
•	Cyanide toxicity should be suspected when the patient develops metabolic acidosis or becomes resistant to the hypotensive effects of this drug despite a sufficient infusion rate.

choices.text: Monitoring the effectiveness of ongoing CPR
Monitoring the metabolic acidosis due to cardiac arrest

questions.text:
A 72 old patient is in intensive care following his coronary artery bypass grafting surgery 3 days back. He is intubated and on mechanical ventilation as his vitals are down and his ejection fraction has been keeping low.
He is on an infusion of noradrenaline and dobutamine to keep his blood pressure normal and there is significant deterioration of his condition in the past 12 hours. Suddenly in the middle of the noon, this patient experienced a sudden cardiac arrest and the code blue team was paged and CPR was immediately started.
The patient had an arterial line in place and a continuous capnography was also used to monitor the patient. Which of the following uses of capnography in this situation is justified except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Capnography has several roles at cardiac arrest:
(i) Confirmation that the airway is patent and present within the trachea ( ongoing CPR)
(ii) Monitoring ventilation rate during CPR and avoiding hyperventilation
(iii) Assessing adequacy of chest compressions during CPR- an ETCO2 of more than 10mm hg is a sign of adequate CPR
(iv) Identifying return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC) during CPR- sudden and abrupt rise of ETCO2 to normal value (around 40 mmhg) indicated ROSC
(v) Prognostication during CPR- a consistently low ETCO2 (around 10 mmhg) even after prolonged resuscitation is a sign of poor prognosis in a patient with cardiac arrest.

choices.text: Atypical pseudocholinesterase leading to prolonged apnea and need to give neostigmine to reverse it
Undiagnosed liver dysfunction leading to pseudocholinesterase deficiency and replacement by administration of fresh frozen plasma
Hypothermia leading to prolongation of action of scoline and so warming will resume the neuromuscular function
Phase II blockade due to excessive dose of scoline and continuing mechanical ventilation and sedation the patient.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old female is taken up for a short procedure of dilatation and evacuation of her uterus due to an incomplete abortion. The patient has no past medical history and has never been operative before. A standard general anesthesia is planned with induction with propofol and fentanyl and scoline as a short acting muscle relaxant and a laryngeal mask airway for ventilation. Due to some unexpected bleeding the surgeon took longer than normal for the procedure and the anesthesiologist gave multiple doses of scoline to keep the patient from breathing spontaneously. After the procedure, the patient remained apnoeic for almost 2 hours with no signs of neuromuscular activity, but consciousness was achieved. To identify the cause the anesthesiologist did a neuromuscular monitoring using a peripheral nerve stimulator and found the response on train of four stimulation as shown in image A. which of the following statements about the diagnosis and management of this condition is true?
Image A
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Phase II block:
•    This is a clinical condition of prolonged apnea due to excessive administration of scoline.
•    Usually a cumulative dose of more 7-10 mg\kg or duration of usage for more than 1 hour is known to cause phase II block.
•    This is also called as desensitization block and the mechanism for this is unclear
•    In phase II block the patient can be apnoeic for  1-3 hours or even more
•    On doing neuromuscular monitoring during phase II block, it behaves like a non-depolarising type of block and shows the same characteristics like fade on TOF stimulation.
•    Treatment of phase II block is conservative with continuation of mechanical ventilation with sedation and eventually the patient resumes the neuromuscular function.
•    In rare cases after considerable period of apnea as passed and the drug must have been metabolised , then administration of neostigmine can be tried to expediate the recovery.

questions.text: Capnography (end-tidal co2 monitoring) can help diagnose the following except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	End-tidal co2 monitoring forms part of universal monitoring for anaesthesia and should also be used for all intubations and transfers in icu, emergency departments and elsewhere. 
•	Capnography measures and graphically displays co2 partial pressure over time.
•	The presence or absence of co2, the value of its partial pressure and the shape of the waveform can give valuable information for the diagnosis of many condition
•	A sloping upstroke on the capnograph suggests severe asthma or copd.
•	Oesophageal intubation can be ruled out by capnography, but not an endobronchial intubation.
•	Pulmonary emboli cause v/q mismatch and reduce cardiac output, thus reducing end-tidal co2.
•	Effective cpr leads to increased co2 delivery to the lungs and hence may be monitored with capnography.
•	A hypoxia patient can b diagnosed using a pulse oximeter. 
•	Capnography will have no role in it.

choices.text: It can distinguish between causes of decreased brain activity.
It predicts movement to surgical stimulus.
Higher values represent more cortical activity.

questions.text: Regarding the bispectral index (BIS):
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	The bispectral index is a statistically based, empirically derived complex parameter. 
•	It is a weighted sum of several EEG parameters and provides the user with a dimensionless number which ranges from 0 (equivalent to EEG silence) to 100 (normal cortical electrical activity). 
•	It records the cortical activity of a patient’s brain and, using analysis, gives a raw figure, higher values representing higher levels of cortical activity
•	BIS is best described as a monitor of the depth of the hypnotic component of anaesthesia or sedation. 
Bispectral index values
	80–100 Awake, capable of specific recall
	60–80 Increased sedation, impaired memory but rousable
	40–60 Surgical plane of anaesthesia. Auditory processing and reflex movement are possible, but memory unlikely
	60-40 deep hypnotic state
	40-20 Burst suppression
	0 flat line ( eeg silence)

•	BIS values only give an idea of cortical activity – they cannot distinguish whether a low value is due to anaesthesia or pathological causes of reduced consciousness.

choices.text: It antagonizes the excitatory neurotransmitter glycine at NMDA receptors.
It decreases cerebral metabolic oxygen requirement.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding ketamine are true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•	Ketamine is a phencyclidine derivative that antagonizes the excitatory neurotransmitter glutamate at NMDA receptors. 
•	It produces a state of dissociative anaesthesia, profound analgesia, and amnesia.
•	It is also a potent bronchodilator. 
•	Ketamine is not commonly used as a sedative infusion due to sympathetic nervous system stimulation resulting in increased cardiac work and a rise in cerebral metabolic oxygen consumption. 
•	Hallucinations, delirium, nausea, and vomiting frequently follow its use, but it still has a role in the management of status asthmaticus.

choices.text: Hypnosis occurs through action on the NMDA receptor.
Etomidate can lead to pain during injection.

questions.text: Concerning etomidate:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	Etomidate is an imidazole hypnotic, with a very stable haemodynamic profile and minimal respiratory depression. 
•	Etomidate is hydrophobic at physiologic pH. 
•	To increase solubility, it is formulated as a 0.2 % solution either in 35 % propylene glycol 
•	Etomidate has a very stable haemodynamic profile and minimal respiratory depression but, due to the inhibition of adrenocortical steroid synthesis either after a single dose or with drug infusion, the popularity of etomidate has declined. 
•	It can cause hypnosis through its action on the GABA receptor system.
•	Etomidate reduces CBF and CMRO2 while maintaining the MAP and CPP.
•	An induction dose of etomidate of 0.3 mg/kg reduces intra-ocular pressure.
•	Administration of etomidate has been associated with grand mal seizures and it also seems to cause myoclonic movements (which is not associated with seizure-like activity on EEG).
•	Etomidate causes maximum pain on injection amongst IV induction agents.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old patient is posted for laparoscopic appendicectomy. The child gives a history of cyanotic spells from childhood. The mother says that her child has a heart condition.
Which of the following would be a preferred drug for induction of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ketamine
•	It is a phencyclidine derivative used for induction of anaesthesia.
•	Pharmacodynamic effects:
•	Cardiovascular system: indirect sympathomimetic effects causing hypertension and tachycardia.
•	Respiratory system: min depression of breathing
•	Cns: increase in icp and cmro2
•	Uterus: uterotonic effect
•	Agent of choice in a patient with cyanotic congenital heart disease because increase in SVR (systemic vascular resistance) decreases the right to left shunt and improves oxygenation.

questions.text: Which of the following induction agents can be used safely in long term infusion except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	Etomidate is an imidazole derivative that is used for the induction of general anaesthesia. 
•	Pharmacodynamic effects of etomidate are:
•	Cardiovascular: maintenance of sympathetic tone with maintained cardiac output.
•	Central nervous system: rapid induction of general anaesthesia, involuntary muscle movements, tremor, hypertonus and a reduction in intracranial pressure, intraocular pressure, cerebral blood flow and cerebral metabolic rate, epileptiform activity on the eeg
•	Gastrointestinal: nausea and vomiting
•	Metabolic/endocrine: inhibition of steroid synthesis in the adrenal cortex (reversible inhibition of 11 β-hydroxylase and 17 α-hydroxylase causing a reduction in cortisol and aldosterone synthesis for at least 24 hours following a single dose); 
•	Other side effects of etomidate are pain on injection, venous thrombosis (due to preparation with ethylene glycol) and myoclonus.

questions.text: All the following anaesthetic agents can cause seizure like activity on EEG except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Drugs in anesthesia causing seizure or seizure like activity on eeg:
Inhaled anesthetic agents: enflurane & sevoflurane
Iv induction agents: ketamine , etomidate, methohexitone
Opioid: meperidine

questions.text: A 17-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after getting shot in the eye by a BB gun. On initial assessment, the patient has a subconjunctival hemorrhage of the left eye with deformity of the globe. The patient's vision in that eye is 20/400 at three feet. The clinician uses a fluorescein strip and finds the patient to be Seidel positive at the limbus, extending back into the sclera at the two o'clock position. The clinician decides that the patient needs urgent surgical intervention. Given this patient's clinical presentation, what anesthetic would be preferred in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•	The patient has an open globe injury due to trauma from being shot in the left eye with a BB gun. The patient needs to undergo surgery as soon as possible and will need to be under general anesthesia.
•	Propofol decreases intraocular pressure (IOP), which prevents possible extrusion of the intraocular contents from an increased IOP.
•	Agents that increase intraocular pressure (IOP) are generally contraindicated, due to concern for extrusion of the intraocular contents.
•	Nitrous oxide, succinylcholine, and ketamine all increase the IOP.

questions.text: A patient is experiencing a symptomatic new wide complex QRS rhythm that is unstable. Cardioversion is indicated. He has a high ASA risk score (unstable uncontrolled ischemic heart disease and diabetes) with a Mallampati score of 2. What is the most appropriate sedative agent for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	Etomidate is frequently used for cardiac procedural sedation because it has limited effect on vital signs; there is essentially no cardiac stimulation or suppression.
•	Ketamine may raise heart rate and blood pressure. In the setting of a patient whose cardiac status is tenuous, elevating the heart rate may increase myocardial oxygen demand and thereby increase ischemia. 
•	Fentanyl, used alone, has good analgesic properties via a central mechanism (blunting frontal lobe function) but, in doses sufficient to make painful procedures tolerable, may suppress respirations. 
•	Propofol has a good analgesic and hypnotic properties, it drops peripheral vascular resistance and thus may cause a hypotension. This may compromise cardiac circulation, thus increasing ischemia and decreasing cardiac output.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female was admitted to the ICU due to Guillain-Barre syndrome. Over the last 3 days, she had been showing signs of improvement but required continued propofol sedation and intubation for ventilatory support as well as parenteral nutrition. On her 4th day of admission, she began to show an acute decline in cardiac function. Her labs revealed lactic acidosis, elevated creatine kinase, and hyperkalemia. Which of the following contributed to her worsening status in the ICU?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	Propofol infusion syndrome should be suspected in patients who have had propofol infusing at a rate of over 4 mg/kg/hr for over 48 hours. 
•	Propofol infusion syndrome is characterized by cardiac abnormalities such as bradycardia, rhabdomyolysis, and metabolic acidosis. 
•	Carnitine deficiency, low carbohydrate levels, use of glucocorticoids and mitochondrial disease can be contributors to the development of propofol infusion syndrome.
•	Long term use of propofol can lead to inhibition of carnitine palmitoyltransferase which ultimately can cause a failure of ATP production in the mitochondria causing a build-up of long, medium and short chain fatty acid by-products.
•	Propofol infusion syndrome is characterized by cardiac abnormalities such as bradycardia, rhabdomyolysis, and metabolic acidosis. 
•	Direct myocyte injury can lead to myoglobinuria, hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis.
•	Rhabdomyolysis also correlates with high levels of steroid therapy in some case reports due to proteolysis of the cardiac contractile myofilaments.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male suffering from chronic shoulder pain is undergoing inguinal hernia repair. During the case, the patients' mean arterial pressure is becoming increasingly difficult to maintain above a goal of 65 mmHg. There is no significant blood loss. ETCO2 monitor reads a normal output of 35 mmHg, which has been stable throughout the case. The blood pressure cuff is securely in place. The patients' home medications include over the counter paracetamol, and oral steroid daily. What is the most likely cause of these patients' hemodynamic instability?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


•    Multiple case reports support the link between long term steroid use and adrenal insufficiency, which can predispose a patient to an eventual adrenal crisis, also known as an Addisonian crisis when under an adequate amount of physiologic stress, this case being surgery.
•    Oral long term steroid therapy act as feedback inhibitors on the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis (HPA). 
•    Patients on chronic steroid therapy may experience HPAA suppression, resulting in low CRH and ACTH levels that lead to atrophy of the adrenal zona fasciculata and a decrease in cortisol production
•    Inadequate cortisol production may predispose to vasodilatation and hypotension
•    Steroid induced adrenal insufficiency has been well established in the chronic pain patient population, and best explains this patient's hemodynamic compromise.
•    Massive blood loss is unlikely. 
•    Hemodynamic monitor failure is unlikely as the patients' blood pressure cuff is securely in place. 
•    Decreased cardiac output is unlikely as the ETCO2 monitor reads a normal range and stable output.
•    Steroid should be replaced based on type of surgery

questions.text: Drugs safe to use in porphyria include all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	Porphyria describes a heterogeneous group of diseases characterized by defects in the enzymes involved in the biosynthesis of haem, resulting in the overproduction and excretion of intermediate compounds (porphyrins). 
•	Barbiturates, phenytoin, and sulphonamides are definite precipitants.
•	Etomidate, lignocaine, and chlordiazepoxide are implicated in laboratory studies.

choices.text: It is formed by combining two acetylcholine molecules.
It is a trigger for malignant hyperpyrexia.
Patients with myasthenia gravis are likely to require a reduced dose of Suxamethonium.

questions.text: Concerning Suxamethonium all are true except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	Suxamethonium is formulated by combining two ACh molecules via their acetyl groups.
•	Among its many side effects, it is a known trigger for MH. 
•	Common culprits for anaphylaxis in anaesthesia. 
•	More commonly, it is a cause of postoperative muscle pain, most likely because of widespread fasciculation. 
•	The action of Suxamethonium in patients with myasthenia gravis (MG) is complex. 
•	Since it acts in a similar manner to acetylcholine at poorly functioning ACh receptors, it would be expected that these patients are resistant to Suxamethonium, as they are to acetylcholine.

choices.text: Is a short acting muscle relaxant.
Muscle relaxation may be reversed by the administration of sugammadex.

questions.text: Atracurium:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	Atracurium is a benzylisoquinolinium and therefore unaffected by sugammadex. 
•	Atracurium is well recognized to cause transient histamine release. 
•	Some advocate avoiding atracurium in asthmatic patients due to fears of inducing bronchospasm. 
•	Atracurium is an intermediate acting muscle relaxant.

choices.text: Is derived from pure cis isomer of atracurium.
Produces less histamine release compared to atracurium.
Is eliminated predominantly via Hoffman degradation.
May be preferred over atracurium in asthmatic patients as it is not metabolized to laudanosine

questions.text: Cisatracurium all are true except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) • Cisatatracurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker in the benzylisoquinolinium class. • It is derived from a single cis-isomer of the parent molecule atracurium, of which it comprises approximately 15%. • It was manufactured in an attempt to produce a ‘cleaner’ drug without associated histamine release, and there are no such side effects with cisatracurium. • The majority (up to 80%) of the drug is eliminated via Hofmann degradation, which is temperature and pH dependent • Like atracurium, laudanosine is a recognized metabolite. This tertiary amine is a known CNS stimulant • Cisatracurium is more potent than atracurium • However, onset of muscle relaxation is slower than atracurium, in equipotent doses • Duration of action is similar for both drugs.

questions.text: Which of the following drug should be preferred for rsi in a patient with serum potassium of 5.5 meq\l?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	Scoline is a depolarising muscle relaxant.
•	It causes muscle relaxation by prolonged depolarization of  muscle end plate.
•	Because of persistant depolarization it causes hyperkalemia and therefore should not be used in patients with hyperkalemia.

questions.text: which of the following muscle relaxants will be preferred in a neonate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	Neonates have immature enzyme system and underdeveloped organs and so metabolism of drugs are less and therefore prolonged effects can be seen.
•	Atracurium is unique as its metabolism is by hoffman’s elimination which is an organ independent process of spontaneous degradation of molecule under physiological ph and temperature.
•	Therefore atracurium is a preferred muscle relaxant in neonates.

choices.text: Increased time to onset and duration of action of atracurium
Increased time to onset of atracurium
Sudden bradycardia and hypotension and urticaria.
Sudden difficulty in ventilation and hypotension and flushing of skin.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is being taken to the operating room for same-day surgery, after which she is scheduled to return home. She has no acute complaints. Her past medical history is limited but includes a tonsillectomy 40 years ago with no complications or issues with anesthesia at that time. Her family history is significant for hypertension and diabetes. She drinks alcohol only in social sittings approximately once a week and has never smoked. She has history of asthma. Preoperative vital signs show heart rate 59/minute, blood pressure 128\64 mmHg and temperature 37 C. Physical exam reveals a generally well-appearing healthy 45-year-old female with a Mallampati score of 2 and a full range of motion in her neck. She is given a standard induction with propofol and atracurium as muscle relaxant. What effect is most likely to be seen during induction based on her preoperative course and evaluation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	Atracurium is an amino steroid non depolarising muscle relaxant.
•	Use of atracurium is associated with release of histamine.
•	On fast administration in an individual predisposed to reactive airway disease like asthma, this histamine release can lead to sudden bronchospasm, flushing of the skin along wih hypotension and reflex tachycardia.

choices.text: Paralytic agent used must be rocuronium
This is an expected duration of action for the medication used
The patient has an upregulation of plasma cholinesterase secondary to an extensive history of cocaine abuse
Severe Butyryl cholinesterase deficiency resulted in a significantly decreased clearance of succinylcholine

questions.text: A 57-year-old white male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset diffuse abdominal, sharp stabbing in nature, and radiating directly to the back. His past medical history is only significant for diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidaemia, and hypertension. He has never had a surgical procedure previously and denies a family history of reactions to anesthesia. Electrolytes, urine drug screen, clotting function, and complete blood count are within normal limits except for haemoglobin of 7.9 grams/dL. Due to unstable vital signs, the patient is brought directly to the operating room from the emergency department, for an exploratory laparotomy secondary to a gunshot wound to the abdomen. Rapid sequence intubation (RSI) medications are pushed prior to securing an airway. The patient is paralyzed for 40 mins despite only receiving the single bolus of paralytic medication. What is the best explanation for this prolonged effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	Pseudocholinesterase is also known as butyryl cholinesterase, plasma cholinesterase, serum cholinesterase.
•	Succinylcholine predominantly relies on pseudocholinesterase for its breakdown, causing the usual duration of action (3 -10 minutes to extend to as much as 8 hours).
•	Rapid sequence induction utilizes the depolarizing neuromuscular blockade agent succinylcholine, rather than the non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockade agent rocuronium.
•	Pseudocholinesterase deficiency is commonly diagnosed when medications such as succinylcholine or mivacurium result in unsuspected increased durations of apnea/paralysis.
•	Severe deficiency can lead to prolonged duration of action of drugs metabolised by pseudocholinestrase.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman was undergoing surgery to remove a breast cancer. The anesthesia was induced by thiopental, maintained by isoflurane and supplemented with a nondepolarizing neuromuscular blocker which has a short duration of action and is metabolized by plasma pseudocholinesterase. Which of the following drugs was most likely administered?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	Mivacurium is the only nondepolarizing neuromuscular blocker that is metabolized by plasma pseudocholinesterase. 
•	Because of this rapid metabolism the action of the drug is quite short.
succinylcholine is metabolized by plasma cholinesterase, but it is a depolarizing, not a nondepolarizing neuromuscular blocker.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man, brought to the emergency room after a car accident, required intubation and mechanical ventilation. Patient history was significant for a genetically deficient plasma cholinesterase. A muscle relaxant was administered IV. Which of the following muscle relaxants would be contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


•	Mivacurium and succinylcholine are two neuromuscular blockers metabolized by plasma cholinesterase. 
•	In patients with a genetically induced deficiency of the normal plasma
cholinesterase these drugs can cause apnea of several hours and are therefore contraindicated.

choices.text: Is predominantly excreted by hoffman’s elimination.
Can raise arterial blood pressure and heart rate
Will usually provide intubating conditions within 30 s

questions.text: Rocuronium:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	Rocuronium (Rapid Onset curonium) is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker in the aminosteroid class. 
•	It undergoes almost exclusive hepatobiliary excretion. 
•	Rapid onset (45–60 s) can be achieved with 0.9– 1.2 mg.kg–1, and this dose may be used as part of a ‘modified’ RSI, where there is a reason to avoid suxamethonium.
•	Like the long-acting aminosteroid pancuronium, rocuronium is a mild vagolytic, so may increase heart rate and blood pressure, although this effect is less pronounced than with pancuronium.
•	Rocuronium has been implicated in several cases of anaphylaxis, and, with suxamethonium, is responsible for the majority of cases of anaphylaxis to muscle relaxants. 
•	Bronchospasm is a recognized feature of anaphylaxis, but this does not mean rocuronium is contraindicated in asthmatics. 
•	Indeed, it may be preferred to atracurium, which is more associated with histamine release.

choices.text: No production of toxic waste products.

questions.text: Advantages of the Mapleson systems include all of the following except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	Advantages of using mapleson breathing systems are:
•	The equipment is simple, inexpensive, and rugged. 
•	In coaxial systems (lack, bain), the inspiratory limb is heated by the warm exhaled gas in the coaxial expiratory tubing.
•	Resistance is usually low at flows likely to be experienced in practice
•	A commonly held view is that the work of breathing during spontaneous ventilation is significantly less with these systems than with the circle system. 
•	These systems are lightweight and not bulky. 
•	Changes in fresh gas concentrations result in rapid changes in inspiratory gas composition.
•	Since there is no co2 absorbent, there will be no production of possibly toxic products such as carbon monoxide and compound A.

questions.text: Preferred anaesthetic agent in a patient with hyperthyroidism included?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	In patients with hyperthyroidism, the goal of anesthesia is to avoid an increase in heart rate or sympathetic stimulation.
•	Ketamine, desflurane and meperidine can cause sympathetic stimulation and tachycardia.
•	Conversely anesthetics and techniques that reduce or blunt sympathetic activity are preferred.
•	Sevoflurane for anesthesia and fentanyl and its congeners for analgesia would be preferred.
•	Regional anesthesia when practical might also be efficacious in avoiding sympathetic activation.

questions.text: Which of the following inhaled anesthetic agents has highest risk of development of carbon monoxide in a closed circuit?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Interactions of co2 absorbers with inhaled anesthetic agents:
1: desflurane + barylime\sodalime ( dry) : carbon monooxide production ( highest)
2: sevoflurane + sodalime: compound a ( nephrotoxic)
3: trilene + sodalime : phosgene gas( ards) and dichloroacetylene ( neurotoxic)

questions.text: A 19-year-old female presents to the preoperative suite for her elective breast augmentation surgery. In the interview, she denies any knowledge of medical conditions. She has never had surgery before. She is unaware of any family members who have had issues with general anesthesia. She is on no medications and denies any tobacco and alcohol usage. All her preoperative testing is within normal limits. She consented to general anesthesia. Two hours into her operation, she starts to seize. Which of the following most likely caused her to seize?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	Enflurane is thought to be a pro-convulsant because of the GABA-ergic effects of the anesthetic.
•	It causes paroxysmal epileptiform discharges which are high-amplitude sharp waves.
•	It causes increased neuronal inhibition in the cortex so any small amount of excitation may cause electrical signalling causing seizures.
•	All the other answers have not been known to cause seizures.
•	A by-product of metabolism of atracurium called as laudonosine has seizure potential but it will only manifest in a case of severe renal failure where there will be sufficient accumulation of laudonosine.

choices.text: Allergic reaction to perioperative antibiotic administered.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man American association anaesthesiology class-III (ASA-III) with a history of coronary artery disease, chronic renal disease, and obstructive sleep apnea is taken to the operating room for inguinal hernia repair. He had been seen by a cardiologist and cleared for surgery. General anesthesia via LMA is considered with maintenance using desflurane. Vital signs are normal prior to pre-op, and induction and placement of the LMA are uneventful. Ten minutes later, during surgical prep, the patient's vital signs show HR 115/min, BP 148/96 mmHg, RR 14/min, ETCO2 40 mmhg & SpO2 99%. The end-tidal desflurane value reads 8.5, and the only other medication administered at this point was cefazolin. What is the most likely cause for the patient's clinical condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•	Desflurane, especially when rapidly titrated, will stimulate the sympathetic nervous system.
•	A higher flow rate on the anesthesia machine can lead to an increase in the fraction of inspired volatile, which will yield more rapid titration of anesthetic. This rapid change in end-tidal volatile, rather than a slow titration, can increase HR and BP transiently.
•	In this patient with a history of CAD, sympathetic stimulation should be avoided to prevent further ischemia.
•	While desflurane is a malignant hyperthermia triggering agent, it is unlikely given the patient's modest elevation in EtCO2, which is more likely explained by his history of OSA. The elevation in HR and BP are non-specific, and it would be much more likely to malignant hyperthermia with a much more rapid elevation in EtCO2. 
•	The non-specific nature of isolated tachycardia and hypertension are much more commonly associated with rapid titration of desflurane as opposed to MH in this scenario. 
•	Inadequate depth of anesthesia certainly presents as hypertension and tachycardia. However, it is much less likely in this scenario where the patient has no surgical stimulation yet as the prep is ongoing, and it has been 10 minutes since the stimulation of placing the LMA occurred. 
•	In addition, the patient's MAC is > 1, which is more than adequate given the lack of stimulation at this time. In fact, it is because of the rapid titration of the volatile agent desflurane which likely led to the tachycardia and hypertension. 
•	Allergic or anaphylactic reactions are common with steroidal non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking drugs as well as perioperative antibiotics. 
•	However, it is much more commonly associated with hypotension, tachycardia, and increased peak airway pressures. 
•	The Etiology of this patient's tachycardia and hypertension are much more likely caused by sympathetic stimulation from desflurane. The mechanism by which the sympathetic stimulation occurs is not fully understood, but rapid titration tends to increase the incidence of stimulation.

choices.text: Alpha thalassemia leading to hypotension and subsequent arrhythmias.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy has a medical history complicated by alpha thalassemia intermediate and previous abdominal surgery for intussusception as a toddler. Three days ago, he also had surgery for a congenital hernia repair at a rural hospital. Intraoperatively the case was complicated by hypotension and refractory brady arrhythmias. Which of the following is the mechanism leading to this child's intraoperative complications?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


•	Alpha thalassemia would increase the patient's chance of bleeding, which was not reported as an intraoperative complication.
•	An allergic reaction would be suspected with a subsequent rash and should always be on the differential.
•	This patient's surgery in a rural hospital indicates halothane was likely used. 
•	Infants and children have a relatively higher parasympathetic tone compared to that of an adult. 
•	This paired with halothanes' negative chronotropic properties may induce bradycardia or asystole.

questions.text: A 37-year-old female is scheduled for an elective laparoscopic hysterectomy. Induction was performed using 140 mg propofol and 100 mcg fentanyl with subsequent 70 mg rocuronium. After intubation, anesthesia was rapidly maintained with an inhaled anesthetic. Within the first minute of administering the inhaled anesthetic, the patient’s heart rate decreased from 70 beats per minute to 50 beats per minute, and the blood pressure decreased from 130/70 mmHg to 80\48 mmHg. Which of the following inhalation agents was most likely used to induce the above response?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•    ALL inhaled anesthetic agents are myocardial suppressants except nitrous oxide and xenon.
•    Maximum decrease in SVR is by isoflurane while no change in SVR happens with halothane.
•    Halothane is the only inhaled anesthetic agent to cause bradycardia on administration.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient is taken for a liver transplant surgery for chronic liver failure. He is induced with a combination of etomidate and fentanyl and atracurium as a muscle relaxant. Which of the following would be the inhalational agent of choice for maintenance of anesthesia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	Isoflurane is a preferred agent in a case of liver transplant surgery because of its vasodilatory effects on the liver blood flow and improvement of splanchnic circulation.
•	Amongst muscle relaxants most preferred is cisatracurium.

questions.text: The cylinder size most used on anesthesia machines and for patient transport is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	Size E is the most commonly used size.
•	This is mounted on the back of anesthesia machine and serves a source of emergency gas supply when the pipeline supply decreases.
•	A fully filled size e cylinder will contain 660 litres of a pure gas eg oxygen.

questions.text: Potency of anaesthetic agent can be estimated by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	MAC was described as a measure of anaesthetic potency. 
•	It is defined as the minimum alveolar concentration of anaesthetic at 1 atmosphere (atm), which produces immobility in 50% of subjects exposed to a noxious stimulus, usually a skin incision.
•	The value of MAC is inversely proportional to anesthetic agent potency.
•	Amongst inhaled anesthetic agents methoxyflurane is most potent and nitrous oxide (104) is least potent.
•	Among volatile anesthetic agents desflurane is least potent with a mac of 6.6

choices.text: Switch to another anesthesia machine and administer Dantrolene intravenously.
Discontinue inhaled sevoflurane and cool the patient with topical ice.
Discontinue inhaled sevoflurane and administer Dantrolene intravenously.
Administer IV sodium bicarbonate and cool the patient with topical ice.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy is having a general anesthetic for open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) of an elbow fracture. He was induced with rocuronium, propofol, and fentanyl and after intubation has been maintained on sevoflurane. Approximately 1 hour later the patient
is tachycardic with a heart rate of 133 beats per minute, his end-tidal CO2 is 84 mm Hg, and his temperature is 39°C. What is the best initial approach to treating this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

• Immediately discontinue the inhalational anesthetic and administer 100% oxygen at high flow rates.
• Notify surgeons to abort or terminate surgery. Call for help and for the malignant  hyperthermia cart.
• Administer Dantrolene 2.5 mg/kg. Repeat until malignant hyperthermia has resolved. Continue
Dantrolene 1 mg/kg every 6 hours for another 24–48 hours.
• Place additional IVs, arterial line, and Foley catheter. 
• Treat hyperkalemia with calcium and glucose/insulin.
• Follow serum creatinine kinase and urinary myoglobin and treat any rhabdomyolysis with IV bicarbonate and mannitol.
• Monitor coagulation profile and treat DIC with blood products.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old male with idiopathic scoliosis complains of being unable to see in the postanaesthetic care unit (PACU) after a posterior fusion in the prone position.
This does not improve over the next 2 days. The most likely mechanism is thought to be:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Postoperative visual loss after surgery is a rare but devastating complication after spine surgery in the prone position. 
Hypotension, anemia, prolonged procedure, and high volume crystalloid resuscitation are known risk factors, along with diabetes and peripheral vascular disease in adults. 
Retinal perfusion pressure can be defined as mean arterial pressure (MAP) – intraocular
pressure (IOP); the latter is known to be elevated in the prone position. 
When retinal perfusion pressure declines below a critical threshold, a watershed type infarct occurs, referred to as posterior ischemic optic neuropathy (PION).

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is undergoing resection of a posterior fossa tumour in the sitting position. A sudden decrease in end-tidal carbon dioxide (CO2) associated with an audible change in the precordial Doppler tones most likely originates from:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

• A negative pressure differential between the right atrium and venous elements in the operative field increases the risk of venous air embolism. 
• Either a large hydrostatic gradient (height above heart) or relatively low central filling pressure can exacerbate the risk.
• The greatest risk of venous air embolism in neurosurgery is presented by the dural venous sinuses because of their anatomic resistance to collapse.

questions.text: The following sites allow accurate measures of core temperature except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	Core temperature monitoring is key to the safe practice of anesthesia.
•	The gold-standard measure of core temperature is of blood by a pulmonary artery (PA) catheter. 
•	Good correlation with the gold standard is seen with measures from the oesophagus, nasopharynx and tympanic membrane. 
•	Peripheral monitoring has poor correlation with core temperature eg skin, axilla, oral, rectal temperatures.

choices.text: Increase the ventilation pressures to improve oxygenation.
Salbutamol via tracheal tube or intravenously may be beneficial.
Intravenous corticosteroids should be administered immediately.
The airway device may be changed to a laryngeal mask airway (LMA)

questions.text: A 65-year-old male, heavy smoker, with COPD is having micro laryngeal surgery under general anaesthesia. He is intubated and ventilated. During the procedure, his saturation on pulse oximeter start to dip and he develops an expiratory wheeze, and it is getting difficult to ventilate. Which of the statements below is the most appropriate in the immediate management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	This patient has developed significant bronchospasm.
•	Bronchospasm occurs when smooth muscle in the conducting airways contracts, because of irritability (smokers, asthmatics, volatile anaesthetics), or light plane of anaesthesia.
•	Where bronchospasm is suspected, high-flow oxygen should be delivered, and anaesthesia deepened using a non-irritant volatile (sevoflurane, halothane) or intravenous anaesthetic.
•	Use of short acting bronchodilators i.e. beta 2 agonists like salbutamol intra tracheal or intravenous are highly effective. 
•	Intravenous corticosteroids act more slowly to suppress the underlying inflammatory processes and may be appropriate depending on the cause. 
•	Ventilation using reduced tidal volumes may be required to protect against barotrauma.
•	In a patient with high risk of bronchospasm use of a Laryngeal Mask Airway causes less irritation of the airway and so less chances of development of bronchospasm but in this case it’s a micro laryngeal surgery and so LMA can’t be used as an airway.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child is to be taken for correction of congenital squint. His preoperative course had been uneventful, and all labs are normal. General anesthesia was planned for the surgery with a standard induction of propofol and fentanyl with atracurium as muscle relaxant. The patient was given sevoflurane for the maintenance of anesthesia. 10 mins into the surgery the child suddenly developed bradycardia and hypotension. The surgeon was immediately informed, and he released the pressure on extraocular muscles and child was given iv atropine stat and the heart rate came to normal. This was supposed to be a reflex response very typical of this surgery. What is the efferent neuron of the reflex arc?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•	The oculocardiac reflex (OCR), also known as the Aschner reflex or trigeminovagal reflex (TVR), was first described in 1908 as a reduction in heart rate secondary to direct pressure placed on the eyeball. 
•	It is defined by a decrease in heart rate by greater than 20% following globe pressure or traction of the extraocular muscles. 
•	The reflex most commonly results in sinus bradycardia. However, it also has a reported association with reduced arterial pressure, arrhythmia, asystole, and even cardiac arrest. 
•	This reflex has most notably been depicted during ophthalmologic procedures, more specifically during strabismus surgery; however, it also may be activated by facial trauma, regional anesthetic nerve blocks, and during mechanical stimulation.
•	Paediatric patients are also more susceptible to the detrimental consequences of this reflex secondary to having a greater dependency on heart rate to maintain cardiac output.

Risk Factors
TRIGGERING STIMULI: 
1.	traction to the extraocular muscles (most common)
2.	direct pressure to the globe
3.	ocular manipulation
4.	ocular pain

Anatomy and Physiology
•	The OCR arc consists of an afferent and efferent limb. 
•	The trigeminal nerve, otherwise known as the fifth cranial nerve, serves as the sensory afferent limb. The vagus nerve, also known as cranial nerve ten, comprises the efferent limb of the OCR. 
•	The pathway is initiated by activation of stretch receptors in the ocular and periorbital tissues. 
•	The short and long ciliary nerves conduct impulses that carry the sensory message to the ciliary ganglion. From there the impulses are transported by way of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve to the Gasserian ganglion, followed by the trigeminal nucleus, where the afferent limb will terminate in the central nervous system (CNS). 
•	This stimulates the efferent limb, causing impulses to exit the brainstem and transmit to the myocardium to synapse as the sinoatrial node and activate the vagal motor response. 
•	The resultant effects include negative chronotropy, leading to bradycardia.
COMPLICATIONS
The complications secondary to the OCR are related to the vagal responses and may include the following:
1.	Sinus bradycardia
2.	Arrhythmia
3.	Reduced atrial pressure.
4.	Ventricular tachycardia
5.	Ventricular fibrillation
6.	Multifocal premature ventricular contractions
7.	Ventricular bigeminy
8.	Asystole
9.	Cardiac arrest
10.	Dizziness
11.	Light-headedness
12.	Nausea
13.	Weakness

TREATMENT
•	Only definitive treatment is the immediate cessation of the triggering stimulus.
•	Intravenous atropine has been shown to cause vagolysis and increase the heart rate in an event of OCR.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female is taken up for a laparoscopic removal of gall bladder. The patients past medical history is suggestive of bronchial asthma on regular treatment. Last exacerbation was 4 months back during the onset of winter season. Rest all her lab investigations are normal. The patient is taken for surgery and a cautious general anesthesia is given with ketamine as induction agent and vecuronium as long-acting muscle relaxant for the procedure. Adequate depth of anesthesia is maintained throughout the procedure and the course is uneventful. At the end of the procedure, the patient is extubated while still unconscious but has started to breath spontaneously a technique commonly referred to as “deep extubation”. "Deep extubation," i.e. endotracheal extubation from a deep plane of anesthesia, is theoretically thought to confer which of the following benefits?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•	Deep extubation theoretically decreases the risk of bronchospasm caused by the stimulus of the endotracheal tube in a lighter plane of anesthesia and in the awake state.
•	The awake extubation group was noted to have an increased incidence of coughing, while the deep extubation group showed a higher incidence of airway obstruction relieved by simple airway manoeuvre.
•	Extubation in a deep plane of anesthesia increases the risk of aspiration as the airway is no longer protected once extubated.
•	Deep extubation has not been shown to decrease either time to hospital discharge or length of time of anesthesia care.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man with a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus type 1, and depression presents for elective inguinal hernia repair. The patient is taking lisinopril, metformin, and sertraline. Patient was induced with a standard dose of thiopentone and fentanyl along with atracurium as muscle relaxant. After successful intubation, the patient was maintained on inhalational halothane with mixture of oxygen and nitrous oxide on controlled ventilation. Shortly after that the patient develops tachycardia, muscle rigidity, and hyperthermia. What is the best initial therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	The correct answer is dantrolene. It is the primary drug used for the treatment and prevention of malignant hyperthermia.
•	Malignant hyperthermia is triggered in susceptible individuals primarily by inhalational anesthetic agents and the muscle relaxant succinylcholine. 
•	Malignant hyperthermia is not an allergy but an inherited disorder. Treatment involves giving dantrolene and discontinuing the triggering agent.
•	In the setting of the recent intubation and clinical presentation, malignant hyperthermia is the most logical culprit. 
•	It is a life-threatening clinical syndrome of hypermetabolism involving the skeletal muscle. 
•	It is triggered in susceptible individuals primarily by inhalational anesthetic agents and the muscle relaxant succinylcholine, although other drugs have also been considered as potential triggers. 
•	A typical presentation involves tachycardia, dysrhythmias, rigidity, rapidly increasing temperature, hyperkalemia, sympathetic hyperactivity, disseminated intravascular coagulopathy (DIC), and multi-organ failure. 
•	Cyproheptadine is the treatment of serotonin syndrome. 
•	Propranolol is part of the treatment for thyroid storm. 
•	Sodium bicarbonate can be used as an adjunct to dantrolene and in the treatment of tricyclic antidepressants.

choices.text: Administering dexmedetomidine 0.5 mcg/kg at 20 minutes prior to emergence
Performing the axillary brachial plexus block while the patient was awake
Better padding during the football game
Proper padding and positioning of the patient during surgery

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy suffers a right distal humeral fracture after a football game. The anaesthesiologist performed a right axillary brachial plexus and musculocutaneous nerve blocks for postoperative analgesia after induction of general anesthesia. During emergence, the patient is acutely agitated and violently sits up while his arms were restrained. At the clinic follow up appointment, the patient is having trouble a loss of sensation in left hand, especially in his ring and little fingers. a loss of coordination in fingers. a tingling or burning sensation in his hand. What might have directly avoided this injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	The axillary brachial plexus block is performed at the level of the terminal nerves: radial, ulnar, and median. The musculocutaneous block is also at the level of the terminal nerve.
•	Nerve injury on the side of the block can be due to direct injury to nerve while giving the drug.
•	This case of nerve injury is on the opposite side of the block. 
•	The typical distribution of involvement is ulnar nerve injury which also is most common nerve injured during anesthesia and surgery
•	This could have been due to pressure and entrapment of nerve at the elbow due to wrong position of the patient.

questions.text: "Shivering" is observed in the early part of postoperative period due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Halothane
Sol:  
“Halothane Shakes”
•	Shivering & tremors are common during the immediate postop period following Halothane anaesthesia. 
•	It may be associated with a generalized increase in muscle tone, clonic or tonic. 
•	Pethidine is recommended in management.

choices.text: Glucose is added to bupivacaine to make hypobaric solution.
The preservative methyl paraben is often added as a preservative.
The addition of bicarbonate reduces the amount of the unionized form of the local anaesthetic.
Lidocaine and amethocaine are mixed in equal parts to form a eutectic mixture of local anaesthetic cream.

questions.text: Local anaesthetics are available in various strengths and preparations:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	Typically, the addition of glucose increases the baricity of bupivacaine in order to control spread within cerebrospinal fluid. 
•	The preservative methyl paraben is often added to local anaesthetic and in very rare instances may provoke an allergic reaction. 
•	The addition of bicarbonate to local anaesthetic should increase the amount of the unionized form by increasing local pH. As a result this should increase the speed of onset of anaesthesia.
•	Lidocaine 2.5% and prilocaine 2.5% can be mixed to form a eutectic mixture of local anaesthetics (EMLA). 
•	In the form of a cream it can be used to provide superficial anaesthesia for skin interventions.

choices.text: Amide local anaesthetics are rapidly metabolized by plasma cholinesterase.
Metabolism of bupivacaine is independent of hepatic function.
Ester local anaesthetics are rapidly metabolized in cerebrospinal fluid.
Metabolites from ester hydrolysis are excreted in the urine.

questions.text: Metabolism of local anaesthetics depends on chemical structure.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	Ester local anaesthetics undergo rapid metabolism by pseudocholinesterase enzymes. 
•	The rapid hydrolysis in plasma results in water-soluble metabolites, which are excreted in urine.
•	No metabolism occurs in cerebrospinal fluid and therefore intrathecally placed ester anaesthetics must be absorbed into the vascular system prior to metabolism. 
•	Amide local anaesthetics are primarily metabolized by microsomal P450 enzymes in the liver.
•	Bupivacaine, as an amide, is metabolized in the liver. 
•	It is conjugated to glucuronic acid with only 5% excreted unchanged in the urine. 
•	Hepatic failure generally has to be severe before metabolism is significantly affected.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female is requesting regional anesthesia during labour. The provider plans to perform a nerve block via the transvaginal approach. During the procedure, the patient develops arrhythmias and gets hypotensive. The patient is suffering from which of the complications of this specific procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


•	This patient is undergoing a pudendal nerve block, and she is suffering from local anesthetic toxicity by injecting the local anesthetic in the pudendal artery.
•	A direct injury of the adjacent pudendal artery will not cause sudden arrhythmias.
•	Injury of the bladder during the pudendal nerve block is rare. An injury to the bladder will less likely cause abrupt arrhythmias.
•	The abdominal aorta is less likely to be injured during the pudendal nerve block.

choices.text: The use of a higher dose of anesthetic agent
Premedication with an intravenous opioid such as nalbuphine
Administration of a long-acting anesthetic agent such as bupivacaine
Changing the position of the patient to jack-knife after only one minute of sitting

questions.text: A 31-year old primigravida, pregnant for 38 weeks, was brought to the emergency department. The patient was having labor pains for the past four hours, and her membranes had ruptured three hours ago. The clinician performed a per-vaginal examination, which revealed that her cervix was fully dilated, and the head of the fetus was at station 0. Detailed history taking showed that the patient had no history of any chronic disease or co-morbidity. Her total leukocyte count, platelet count, and coagulation profile were within the normal range. She was prepared to deliver, and saddle block anesthesia was planned as a method for labor analgesia. The duration of labor was prolonged, and the effect of analgesia wore off earlier than anticipated. What measure can be taken while performing the said neuraxial block to ensure a prolonged duration of analgesia without the added risk of narcotizing the baby?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	Saddle block anesthesia has various disadvantages. Less than the desired duration of analgesia is one of them. 
•	The use of longer-acting anesthetic agents such as bupivacaine can provide a more prolonged period of analgesia.
•	It a safer to use in labor as it allows a low dosage of the drug and yields a prolonged duration of analgesia without the risk of narcotizing the fetus.
•	This agent has been used in obstetrics with no increase in fetal or maternal morbidity and mortality.
•	The use of a higher dose of the anesthetic drugs may pose deteriorating effects on the fetus. 
•	Intravenous administration of opioids can cause respiratory depression in the fetus. 
•	Jack-knife position has no role in the duration of analgesia produced by the saddle block.

choices.text: Action of lignocaine is increased in alkaline environment
Dependent on uncharged molecules crossing the cell membrane
Action of lignocaine is decreased in acidic environment
Deeper block with increasing action potential frequency

questions.text: A 17-year-old female is suffering from large breast abscess. She has to be taken for incision and drainage. Due to unavailability of an anesthesiologist the surgeon decides to perform the procedure under local infiltration. After routine investigation and adequate preoperative fasting, the patient is taken up for surgery. The surgeon aspirates 15 ml of 2 % lignocaine for anesthesia and infiltrates the abscess all around the margins and the apex of the abscess as well. After waiting for 5 mins for the action of lignocaine to take effect he takes a stab knife and takes the incision. Immediately the patient winces in pain and becomes hypertensive and tachycardiac. Which ONE of the following statements best describes this local anaesthetic activity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	local anesthetics act by inhibition of impulse transmission by blocking the sodium channels on the nerve membrane
•	the site of action of local anesthetic molecule is the inactivation gate which lies intracellularly
•	so for the onset of action the local anesthetic molecule has to be in an unionized form
•	all local anesthetic molecules are weak bases which are unionized in a basic medium and ionized in an acidic medium
•	any area of inflammation eg an abscess cavity is highly acidic in nature and so the efficacy of local anesthesia will be decreased
•	therefore one cannot perform a local infiltration anesthesia in an inflamed tissue.

choices.text: Give an initial intravenous bolus injection of 20 % lipid emulsion 1.5 mL/kg over 1 min.

questions.text: A frail 75-year-old woman was brought to emergency with a Colle’s fracture of the left wrist. A junior orthopaedic trainee manipulated the wrist using intravenous regional anaesthesia (Bier’s block) with 30 mL of 0.25 % levobupivacaine. Shortly after the cuff was deflated, the patient had symptoms of confusion, seizure, and hypotension, without cardiorespiratory arrest. The most appropriate next step in the management would be:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

This lady has Local Anaesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST) without cardiorespiratory arrest, as the local anaesthetic used was levo-bupivacaine rather than prilocaine, which is advised for Bier’s block as is less cardiotoxic.
This is a form of CNS toxicity due to release of large amounts of local anesthetic in systemic circulation after release of tourniquet in bier’s block.
Signs of severe toxicity include:
•	Sudden alteration in mental status, severe agitation, or loss of consciousness, with or without tonic-clonic convulsions.
