•	Cardiovascular collapse: sinus bradycardia, conduction blocks, asystole, and ventricular tachyarrhythmias
Local anaesthetic (LA) toxicity may occur sometime after an initial injection.
Immediate management steps are:
1.	Stop injecting the LA.
2.	Call for help.
3.	Maintain the airway and, if necessary, secure it with a tracheal tube.
4.	Give 100 % oxygen and ensure adequate lung ventilation (hyperventilation may help by increasing plasma pH in the presence of metabolic acidosis).
5.	Confirm or establish intravenous access.
6.	Control seizures: give a benzodiazepine, thiopental, or propofol in small incremental doses. Assess cardiovascular status throughout.
7.	Consider drawing blood for analysis, but do not delay definitive treatment to do this.
Without circulatory arrest Use conventional therapies to treat:
•	hypotension
•	bradycardia
•	tachyarrhythmia.
Use of intralipid is done in the management of cardiovascular toxicity associated with LAST.

questions.text: Which property of local anesthetic denotes its duration of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•	Duration of action of a local anaesthetic is defined by its lipid solubility.
•	More lipid soluble agents are longer in duration of action.
•	This can also be expressed in term of octanol solubility

questions.text: All of the following are ester type of local anesthetic except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	Local anesthetic molecules comprise of aromatic benzene ring and a tertiary amine.
•	Both of these are joined by an intermediate chain.
•	Based on the chemical structure of this intermediate chain, local anesthetics are divided into 2 types:
1: ester local anesthetics: eg procaine, benzocaine, tetracaine, chloroprocaine 
2: amide local anesthetics: eg lignocaine, bupivacaine, prilocaine, ropivacaine

questions.text: Which of the following types of regional anesthesia is associated with the GREATEST serum concentration of lidocaine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•	The site of injection of the local anesthetic is one of the most important factors influencing systemic local anesthetic absorption and toxicity. 
•	The degree of absorption from the site of injection depends on the blood supply to that site. 
•	Areas that have the greatest blood supply have the greatest systemic absorption. 
•	For this reason, the greatest plasma concentration of local anesthetic occurs after an intercostal block, followed by caudal epidural, lumbar epidural, brachial plexus, sciatic/femoral nerve block, and subcutaneous

questions.text: Which state of local anesthetic molecule is required for its action:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•	Local anesthetics are Na+ channel blockers.
•	The site of action is the intracellular surface of the channel.
•	For the drug to reach its site of action it needs to be in unionized form i.e lipophilic form to cross the cell membrane.
•	But the active form of LA is its ionized form and it is present around receptor intracellularly

questions.text: All of the following are proven benefits of epidural analgesia except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	Epidural analgesia as a part of enhanced recovery programme has been shown to shorten hospital stay. 
•	It also has been shown to decrease ileus, provide better analgesia, and improve pulmonary function. 
•	However, none of the epidural studies or systematic reviews has shown long-term survival benefits.

questions.text: Complications of supraclavicular brachial plexus block include all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Complications of supraclavicular brachial plexus blockade include:
•	pneumothorax
•	phrenic and recurrent laryngeal block
•	Horner’s syndrome
•	subclavian vessel puncture.
•	Infraclavicular brachial plexus black shares the same complications, but with a reduced risk of pneumothorax.
•	Interscalene block complications include those of supraclavicular (barring pneumothorax and subclavian puncture) and extradural or intrathecal injections and vertebral artery puncture.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primipara has an accidental dural tap (ADT) with a 16-G tuohy needle while the anaesthetist was attempting labour epidural analgesia. A day after the ADT, the patient is complaining of severe positional frontal and occipital headache. Which of the following is not appropriate 1st line management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Management of PDPH
Conservative management approaches include:
•	bed rest
•	encouraging intake of oral fluids and/or intravenous hydration
•	reassurance.
routine bed rest after dural puncture is not beneficial and should be abandoned.

Pharmacological approaches include:

choices.text: LP can be performed at any lumbar level.
Incidence of post-dural puncture headache (pdph) is reduced using a 25g Pencil-point needle.
Contraindications include coagulopathy, patient refusal and local infection
Position of the patient is usually lateral.

questions.text: Regarding lumbar puncture (LP) which of the following is true except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•	Lumbar puncture is a procedure for removing cerebrospinal fluid (csf) for therapeutic or diagnostic purposes. 
Indications for lp include:
•	Diagnosis of meningitis and encephalitis
•	Diagnosis of subarachnoid haemorrhage (xanthochromia)
•	Diagnosis of multiple sclerosis, sarcoidosis, guillain–barr´e syndrome and other conditions
•	Measurement of csf pressure
•	Therapeutic drainage of csf (e.g. Benign intracranial hypertension)
•	Intrathecal injection (spinal anaesthesia, cytotoxic drugs, contrast)
Absolute contraindications are limited to patient refusal and local infection.
Relative contraindications include sepsis, coagulopathy, and congenital abnormalities (e.g. Meningocele). 
•	Extreme caution should be exercised for lp in the presence of raised icp. 
•	Release of csf pressure in the spine can lead to herniation of posterior fossa structures through the foramen magnum (‘coning’), which leads to brainstem compression and death. 
•	The procedure is performed under strict aseptic conditions. 
•	Patients are commonly placed in the lateral decubitus position with maximal head, neck, hip and knee flexion to reduce lumbar lordosis, but lp may be performed on the sitting patient (although csf pressure measurement will be impaired). 
•	The needle should pass along the midline from the skin, between spinous processes of the lower lumbar vertebrae, through the ligamentum flavum, dura mater and arachnoid to enter the subarachnoid space.
•	The level chosen for lp should be below the end of the spinal cord. 
•	This is usually around lower border of L1 in adults, but is lower in children and in the presence of spinal cord tethering. 
•	The l4/5 interspace is commonly chosen for this reason.
•	Complications include haemorrhage (including spinal or epidural haematoma), infection (cellulitis, meningitis, epidural or spinal abscess), post-dural puncture headache (pdph), neurological damage (temporary and permanent) and cerebral herniation. 
•	Incidence pf pdph can be reduced by using a thin needle with pencil point tip.

questions.text: Complications of the interscalene approach to the brachial plexus include
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


All of above

All are known complications of Interscalene approach of brachial plexus block
Phrenic nerve block is the most common complication of interscalene approach seen in 100 % individuals.
Apart from this we can get vagus nerve damage, brain stem anesthesia, vertebral artery injection, recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis etc.

questions.text: Five hours after performing a left-sided interscalene brachial plexus injection of 40 mL of 0.25% bupivacaine (for analgesia), the provider is called to evaluate the patient for hypoxemia. Pulse oximetry is 86%, bilateral breath sounds are heard on chest auscultation, and chest x-ray demonstrates elevated left hemidiaphragm with no signs of pneumothorax. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	A potential cause of elevation of the left hemidiaphragm is ipsilateral phrenic nerve palsy.
•	Phrenic nerve palsy is a potential complication of interscalene approach.
•	Phrenic nerve palsy may result in hypoxemia especially if there is concurrent pulmonary pathology.
•	In a normal chest x-ray, the right hemidiaphragm is usually slightly elevated compared to the left hemidiaphragm.

questions.text: A healthy 29-year-old, 0 para female in gestation week 39, was planned for saddle block labor analgesia. The patient was taken to the operating room and prepared for the procedure. Her baseline vitals were recorded; the blood pressure was 130/80 mm Hg, the heart rate was 86/min, and the cardiac monitor showed a sinus rhythm electrocardiogram (ECG). The patient was maintained in an upright sitting position. The anesthesia was induced via a 25 G Quincke cutting needle inserted at L4-5 interspinous space. The subarachnoid space was at a depth of about six cms from the skin surface, and it was confirmed by the presence of clear cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) dripping from the needle. The syringe containing the recommended standard dose of hyperbaric bupivacaine was attached to the spinal needle. The anesthesiologist overlooked the step to re-aspirate CSF into the needle and proceeded with the intrathecal administration of the drug. After completion of the injection, blood-tinged fluid dripped from the back of the spinal needle. Early in labor, the patient suddenly developed hypotension and was immediately administered with a suitable vasopressor. Soon after, the ECG showed an abnormal rhythm. The patient collapsed from the sudden arrhythmia. What is the complication that led to the systemic toxicity of the anesthetic drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	The presence of blood-tinged fluid in the spinal needle confirms the intravascular lodgment of the needle. Failure to aspirate the clear cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) after attaching the syringe to the spinal needle demands to reposition the needle, and it is a crucial step while performing the saddle block anesthesia.
•	Bupivacaine is a cardiotoxic drug. The inadvertent intravascular injection can produce very high serum drug levels.
•	The high serum levels of bupivacaine affect the cardiovascular system by causing hypotension, depressed cardiac contractility, and arrhythmias.
•	The total spinal block causes motor paralysis that presents as upper extremity weakness and respiratory depression which requires emergent endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation. 
•	A traumatic neuraxial block may cause epidural hematoma that causes sharp back and leg pain accompanied by lower extremity motor weakness. 
•	Cauda equina syndrome is caused by compression or damage to nerve roots and has a presentation similar to epidural hematoma.

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient is taken for a ORIF of proximal radius and ulna fracture. There is no past medical history. all investigations are normal except that the patient is obese and has a thick neck. He is an anticipated difficult intubation. An axillary nerve block is performed. On incision, the patient complains of pain anterolateral forearm. Which nerve has been missed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Axillary approach to brachial plexus block

 
•    The axillary approach is most commonly used because it is relatively easy and has few side-effects. 
•    It is suitable for surgery to the forearm, wrist and hand, though the radial side( antero lateral) of the forearm is sometimes missed. 
•    This can be addressed by blocking the musculocutaneous nerve separately by injecting local anaesthetic in the belly of the coracobrachialis muscle, just superior to the pulsation of the axillary artery and at 90° to the skin. 
•    Because the injection is made at the level of the terminal branches, the missed segment(s) show a nerve territory distribution and not a dermatomal pattern, as is the case when the injection is placed at the level of the roots
•    Axillary approach is easiest as there is no risk of pneumothorax and phrenic nerve palsy due to distal injection.
•    The relative arrangement of 3 terminal nerves (radial , median and ulnar nerve) to axillary artery is fairly constant in axilla.

choices.text: Rush the patient to the operating room for urgent craniotomy
Monitor the patient for respiratory depression
Reassure the patient that this type of headache is normal after delivery

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient G2P2 on a postpartum day 2 complaints about having an "intense headache." The patient reports that the headache started in the morning and describes it as an intense frontal headache, severity 7/10, improves with lying down, worsens with sitting up, accompanied by blurry vision, nausea, and tinnitus, and not relieved by acetaminophen. The patient had an uneventful vaginal delivery at 38 weeks of gestation with continuous epidural infusion for pain management. Which of the following actions is the most appropriate for this patient's current presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


•	Accidental dural puncture with an epidural needle when attempting catheter placement in the epidural space is a complication of the procedure.
•	Post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) can occur as a consequence.
•	Epidural blood patch consists of the injection of autologous blood on the epidural space and has been proven effective on PDPH treatment.
•	Patients receiving neuraxial anesthesia with opioids should always be monitored for respiratory depression. 
•	Subdural hematoma should also be considered in this patient but rushing her to the operating room for craniotomy would not be the most appropriate next action.

questions.text: You have given an interscalene block for a patient undergoing shoulder surgery. However, about 30 min after the block, the patient finds that his voice is getting hoarse, and he is finding it difficult to speak. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•	Recurrent laryngeal nerve block is a well-known complication after interscalene block, which can cause hoarseness of voice due to ipsilateral paralysis of vocal cord.
•	The other mentioned complications are possible but are unlikely to be responsible for change in voice.

questions.text: Intrathecal fentanyl is useful for postoperative analgesia after caesarean section, but which of the following is the most common side effect of using it?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•	The incidence of itching after intrathecal diamorphine is 60–80 % , although only a minority actually need treatment. 
•	Nausea occurs in about 30 % . 
•	Respiratory depression is quite rare as pregnancy increases the sensitivity of respiratory centre. 
•	Sedation is also rare. 
•	Urinary retention is uncommon and does not matter as the patients are catheterized anyway.

choices.text: Sedation vacation and spontaneous breathing trial
Do a spontaneous breathing trial on sedative medications

questions.text: A 31-year-old patient with a past history for asthma presented to the ER with difficulty in breathing and cough. Examination shows that he was using accessory muscles and lung auscultation showed extensive expiratory wheezing. Labs and chest x-ray were unremarkable. He did not respond to nebulizations, steroids, and IV magnesium treatment. He was put on non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (BiPAP) by an ER physician which again he didn't tolerate. Eventually, he was intubated and to achieve better patient-ventilator synchrony he was deeply sedated. The second day in ICU his wheezing is much better. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	The patient is doing well, and his asthma exacerbation is getting better.
•	In many of these patients, an estimated 33% of all admissions, are admitted for the respiratory failure of one etiology or another and subsequently are intubated and placed on mechanical ventilatory control.
•	Part of the standard of care for intubation is to sedate the patient continuously to reduce pain and anxiety; decrease oxygen consumption, and the body’s stress response; prevent patient-ventilator desynchrony; reduce adverse neurocognitive impacts such as depression and post-traumatic stress disorder and ventilator-associated events including pneumonia and tracheostomy, and reduce total nursing requirements.
•	Regardless of which sedative agent was utilized, total continuous sedation was found to be associated with an extension of the total length of intubation and increased length of the ICU stay and limited the ability to properly assess the mental status of the patient, increased the risk for delirium, and suppressed brainwave function seen on EEG, linking to increased 6-month mortality. 
•	It was assessed that daily, short-term cessation of sedation, a “sedation vacation,” led to improved outcomes in patient care.

choices.text: Left groin exploration and control of hemorrhage

questions.text: A 17-year-old male is brought to the trauma bay following a gunshot wound to the left groin. The patient is noted to be obtunded, and his Glasgow coma scale (GCS) is 7/15. EMS reports that the patient was found in a large pool of blood in an alleyway. The incident was not witnessed, and it is unclear how long the patient was down. The pressure is currently being held on the groin. Vitals include heart rate 127/min, blood pressure 82/40 mmHg, and respiratory rate 27/min. The patient is unable to provide any information. What is the immediate next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

•	As with any trauma, ATLS principles teach airway, breathing, circulation.
•	Given the patient's poor GCS, he is at risk for respiratory decline as he is unable to protect his airway.
•	The first step in trauma management should be endotracheal intubation.
•	Endotracheal tube insertion is achieved by the principle of RSI(Rapid Sequence Intubation).
•	Groin exploration is likely warranted in an emergent setting once primary and secondary trauma surveys are complete. 
•	Interventional radiology (IR) intervention is not recommended for proximal extremity vascular injuries, and the patient is too unstable to take to IR. 
•	Large volume(>1.5L) crystalloid resuscitation is associated with increased risk of mortality.
•	Volume resuscitation should proceed with blood products is preferred over large volume fluid resuscitation.

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient with chronic renal failure presents for hip arthroscopy to address and treat his labral tears and associated hip pain. The best option for opioid therapy in this patient is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	Chronic pain is common in chronic kidney disease and most will rate this pain as moderate to severe.
•	The absorption , metabolism and renal clearance of opioids are complex in renal failure.
•	However with appropriate selection and titration of opioids , patients with renal failure can achieve analgesia with minimal risk of adverse effects.
•	Meperidine is not recommended due to accumulation of normeperidine which may precipitate seizures and prolonged respiratory depression.

questions.text: The following may be measured by device shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The pulmonary artery (pa) catheter was developed by swan and ganz in 1970. 
It became very popular as a means of measuring physiological parameters that could not otherwise be measured in vivo, such as cardiac output.
Pa catheters are inserted into a central vein (internal jugular, subclavian or femoral) and advanced through the right atrium, tricuspid valve, right ventricle and pulmonary valve into the pulmonary artery. 
Pressure may be measured as it passes through these structures. 
Once sited in the pulmonary artery, a balloon is inflated to occlude the artery and obtain a pcwp distal to the occluding balloon. 
A  continuous column of static blood then exists between the balloon and the left atrium, and so the pcwp is an indirect measure of lap and hence lvedp.
Cardiac output measurement are by intermittent thermodilution with cold saline, using the indicator dilution method. 
This method remains the gold standard of cardiac output measurement, against which all novel cardiac output monitors are judged.

choices.text: Reduce the inspired inhalation concentration of isoflurane.
Stop the surgeon operating and release the muscles of the globe.

questions.text: A 54-year-old patient is having retinal detachment surgery under general anaesthetic. During the surgery the patient became bradycardic with heart rate of 40 beats per minute and blood pressure of 75/40. What is the first thing would you do?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	The oculo-cardiac reflex (OCR) can occur secondary to traction on the eye and ocular muscles, resulting in bradycardia. 
•	Occasionally it can cause junctional rhythm or asystole. 
•	The afferent pathway is ciliary ganglion to ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve to gasserian ganglion to main trigeminal sensory nucleus fourth ventricle. 
•	The efferent pathway is the vagus nerve. 
•	The first step in managing OCR is to releasing the traction on the eye. 
•	Persistent bradycardia should be treated with anticholinergic drugs. 
•	Intravenous atropine sulphate blocks the peripheral muscarinic receptors at the heart, and release of traction blocks the conduction at ciliary ganglion on the afferent limb of OCR. 
•	Atropine or glycopyrrolate can be used to treat this reflex and it can be given prophylactically. 
•	Hypoxia, hypercarbia, and light anaesthesia potentiate this reflex and should be avoided. 
•	Retrobulbar block does not guarantee attenuation of this reflex.

choices.text: Can provide full ventilation support to an apnoeic patient.
Can utilize volume-preset or pressure-preset ventilation.
Allows the patient to breathe spontaneously
Reduces the likelihood of breath stacking and volutrauma.

questions.text: Synchronized intermittent mandatory ventilation (SIMV) was an improvement on intermittent mandatory ventilation (IMV) because it
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	Choices A, B, and C describe features that are common to both IMV and SIMV.
•	SIMV allows a patient’s respiratory effort to initiate mandatory ventilator-supported breaths; while in IMV, the mandatory breaths are delivered on a preset schedule without regard for the patient’s spontaneous breaths. 
•	Therefore, ventilation with IMV has a higher risk of breath stacking and volutrauma, as a patient can take a large spontaneous breath just prior to the ventilator delivering a mandatory breath.

Techniques of cardiac output monitoring:
Classified based on invasiveness:
Invasive techniques:

Less invasive techniques:

2.	Ultrasound flow dilution

5.	Transesophageal echocardiography
6.	Esophageal Doppler
Non-invasive techniques
1.	Transthoracic echocardiography

3.	Bioimpedance

5.	Ultrasonic cardiac output monitoring

He assesses the responsiveness and pulse and immediately starts cardiopulmonary resuscitation and calls for help by dialling 911. During cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) he performs external chest compression at the rate of 90/min with 2 inches of sternal depression. The most appropriate action is to:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

choices.text: Always analyse rhythm before starting CPR
CPR should always be carried out for 2 minutes prior to defibrillation
Two minutes of chest compressions alone (no ventilation) should be carried out prior to first shock
If AED is available immediately then deliver one biphasic shock then five cycles of CPR

questions.text: Select the TRUE statement regarding cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and defibrillation by a health care provider in patients experiencing sudden cardiac arrest.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	Delays in either starting CPR or defibrillation reduce survival from SCA. 
•	Thus the 2015 AHA Guidelines for CPR and ECC recommend that for adult witnessed cardiac arrests when an AED is immediately available, the defibrillator should be used as soon as possible. 
•	For adults with unmonitored cardiac arrest or for whom an AED is not immediately available, it is reasonable that chest compressions be initiated while the defibrillator equipment is being retrieved and applied, and that defibrillation, if indicated, be attempted as soon as the device is ready for use.
•	Recall one cycle of CPR is 30 compressions and two breaths. 
•	After the shock, continue CPR for five cycles, then check for a pulse.

questions.text: Where should you attempt to perform a pulse check in an adult?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sites of pulse check
Adult: carotid artery
Child: femoral \ carotid artery
Neonate: brachial artery

questions.text: After delivering a shock, what is the next step in caring of a cardiac arrest victim?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Immediately after delivery of the shock the rescuer should continue the chest compressions as it improves the outcome by minimum cessation of blood flow to brain.

questions.text:
you are a daycare provider and find a 3-year-old child who is unresponsive. She had laid down for a nap because she was not feeling well. When you checked on her, she was not breathing and appeared blue. You are by yourself. 
What is the first step in managing this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

In an unwitnessed collapse in paediatric victim , its suggested to give 2 mins of cpr before leaving the victim to activate the emergency response system and call for help as most cardiac arrests in a pediatric patients has a respiratory cause rather than cardiac cause and give 2 mins of cpr will benefit the patient more.

questions.text: A 32-year-old was having dinner when suddenly he couldn’t breathe and started showing universal choking sign. A bystander immediately took notice and did something to help the patient which is shown in the image below. Which of the following maneuver is being shown?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	A person who is choking cannot talk, cough, or breathe, and may turn gray or blue. 
•	The Heimlich maneuver can help get the food or object out. 
•	If the person can cough or make sounds, let him or her cough to try to get the object out. 
•	If the person can't breathe, cough, or make sounds, then:
•	Stand or kneel behind the person and wrap your arms around his or her waist. If the person is standing, place one of your legs between his or her legs so you can support the person if he or she faints.
•	Make a fist with one hand. Place the thumb side of your fist against the person's belly, just above the belly button but well below the breastbone.
•	Grasp your fist with the other hand. Give a quick upward thrust into the belly. This may cause the object to pop out. You may need to use more force for a large person and less for a child or small adult.
•	Repeat thrusts until the object pops out or the person faints.

choices.text: Do not check for breathing, continue chest compressions

questions.text: How long should you check for breathing while performing CPR?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Do not stop CPR for more than 10 seconds to check for breathing and pulse

choices.text: Repeat the head tilt/chin lift maneuver and attempt the breath again

questions.text: When you try to give an unresponsive adult a rescue breath and the chest does not appear to rise, what would you do next?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	Attempt a breath, and if it goes in, deliver a second breath. If unable to ventilate, assume an additional foreign body is present.
•	The airway is most commonly obstructed by posterior displacement of the tongue or epiglottis. 
•	If there is no evidence of cervical spine instability, a head-tilt chin-lift should be tried first . 
•	One hand (palm) is placed on the patient’s forehead applying pressure to tilt the head back ( extension) while lifting the chin with the forefinger and index finger of the opposite hand. 
•	The jaw-thrust may be more effective in opening the airway( lifts the tongue from posterior pharyngeal wall) and is executed by placing both hands on either side of the patient’s head, grasping the angles of the jaw, and lifting.

choices.text: Wipe off the face or cover with a shirt

questions.text: Arriving first to the scene, you find an unresponsive person with no pulse that has thrown up. You feel CPR is not something you are comfortable giving them. What would be the next best thing for you to do?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	Only CPR has been shown to be effective. Leaving the victim significantly increases mortality.
•	The COLS ( Compression Only Life Support) emphasises on early recognition of cardiac arrest and activation, early chest compression and early transfer to medical facility. 
•	The guidelines emphasise avoidance of any interruption of chest compression, and thus relies primarily on chest compression-only CPR by laypersons.

Check pulse, attach electrode pads, analyze rhythm, shock patient

questions.text: When operating an AED, what are the correct steps to follow?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	The patient must be analyzed before the AED will advise a shock 
•	This represents the correct steps for operating an AED. 
•	The rhythm must be analyzed before the AED will advise a shock. 
•	A pulse check should have been done prior to attaching the AED and is not part of AED operation.
